title: How to Access iMessages on iCloud: 2 Simple Methods

steps.title: Update to iOS 11.4.
steps.content: Update to iOS 11.4. If you haven't already done so, update the operating system on your iPhone to iOS 11.4 or later. Read "How To Update iOS" to learn how to update latest version of iOS on your iPhone or iPad.

steps.title: Open the Settings app.
steps.content: Open the Settings app. The Settings app has an icon that resembles two gears. It's on your home screen.

steps.title: Tap your name.
steps.content: Tap your name. Your name is at the top of the Settings menu next to your profile picture. This opens the Apple ID menu.

steps.title: Tap iCloud.
steps.content: Tap iCloud . It's next to the icon that resembles a blue cloud.

steps.title: Tap the switch next to Messages.
steps.content: Tap the switch next to Messages. The Messages or iMessage app has a green icon with a white speech bubble. This enable iMessage messages to be stored on iCloud. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Update to MacOS High Sierra.
steps.content: Update to MacOS High Sierra. If you don't have the latest version of MacOS, you need to update to MacOS 10.13.5 to enable Messages on iCloud. Read "How to Upgrade Mac System Software" to learn how to upgrade to the latest version of MacOS.

steps.title: Open Messages.
steps.content: Open Messages. Messages is the app that has a large blue speech bubble and a small white speech bubble.

steps.title: Click Messages.
steps.content: Click Messages . It's in the upper-right corner of the screen in the menu bar when the Messages app is open.

steps.title: Click Preferences.
steps.content: Click Preferences . It's in the Messages menu. This opens the Preferences app.

steps.title: Click the Accounts tab.
steps.content: Click the Accounts tab. It's the second tab at the top of the Preferences window. It has an icon with a blue circle with a white "@" sign in the middle.

steps.title: Check "Enable Messages in iCloud".
steps.content: Check "Enable Messages in iCloud". It has a checkbox next to it you can check under the "Account tab in the preferences window. This enables iMessage messages to be stored on iCloud. [3] X Research source
